A subscription service is a system where game companies charge a certain amount of money in exchange for users accessing their game every week/month/year or other predetermined period of time.

Micro-transactions are in-game items that the users can purchase using real money. The problem with micro-transactions is that the difficulty of the game is made in such a way that the players cannot progress in a reasonable amount of time without paying for said micro-transactions. Another problem is that those in-game items are created in such a way that if the players want to keep winning, they will have to keep buying them endlessly, potentially spending thousands of dollars (or any other real-life currency).

A battle pass is a subscription service for the potential to win in-game items. It is usually split into a basic battle pass (free) and a premium battle pass, with the premium version offering better rewards than the basic one. All battle passes are designed in such a way that the player has to keep playing the game to get better and better rewards, making it addictive in the process.

Loot boxes are micro-transactions that contain different prizes which can only be obtained randomly, similar to gambling. The worst aspects of those boxes is that sometimes the player can get absolutely nothing, the rewards are usually useless and the best prizes can only be obtained if the player opens hundreds or even thousands of such boxes. Loot boxes, of course, can be divided into boxes with potentially useful prizes and boxes with fairly useless prizes.

Pay-to-win is the name of a type of game that implements practices designed to make the user spend exorbitant amounts of money for a chance to win. Not all games that implement micro-transactions are necessarily pay-to-win, as useful prizes can usually be obtained just by playing, without the need to spend real money. However, in cases where it is clear that a game cannot be completed or even played without the user spending money on loot boxes, battle passes or other micro-transactions, it is marked as pay-to-win.

Other malicious practices are hidden psychological tricks added to make players spend more money without realizing it. Such tricks may include creating more in-game coins so that the user does not think twice when spending them, with the main purpose being to dilute the value of real money.

Concerning Terms of Service are crafted in such a way that it legally allows the company that owns the game to screw the user without repercussion, either by stealing all of their data, denying refunds, or even monitoring their device.
Fake engagement refers to buying positive reviews for a game. Not on this platform, though.

When a game is labeled as such, it means that all promotional art created to advertise the game completely misrepresents the final product. For example: a company releases a trailer (short video that should realistically present the game) that makes it look like their game contains the ability to shoot enemies. In reality, after the users download it, expecting what they saw in the trailer, they find out that it\'s just a generic game of managing a base and its resources, no shooting included.

Immoral developers usually lie to their community, for example by making false promises. It could also mean they or the company they work for has allegations or convictions of employee misconduct (for example, workplace harassment).
What is defined as a scam?

A game labeled with \"scam\" is a game that was advertised to convince people to buy it, either at launch, by pre-ordering, or by investing money before it was even created, but turned out to be incomplete, with major bugs and generally a total disappointment at launch. A good example would be the following: developers start a campaign to raise funds for the creation of a promised game, but the money obtained is used more for the personal interests of the people behind the campaign (in other words, the money is stolen). When the time comes for the game to be released, it doesn\'t look even remotely similar to what was promised (and what people invested their own money in) because there weren\'t enough funds left to develop that version of the game.
